en: Two historical manuscript images served as IIIF resources from static tiles on GitHub Pages. Prepared for the AI + History Collaboratory session on 24 February 2026.
First page of the first issue of the Ottoman Government Gazette (Takvim-i Vekayi), published in Istanbul

body.value:
Masthead

Original Scriptتقویم وقایع
TransliterationTaḳvîm-i Veḳâyi'
Literal EnglishCalendar of Events
Modernized EnglishCalendar of Events [Official Ottoman Gazette]

Publication details:

دفعه ١Def'a 1Issue 1
شروع فی جا ٢٥Şürû' fî Cumâde'l-âḫir 25Commencing 25 Jumada al-Akhir
١٢٤٧ سنه1247 SeneYear 1247 AH [1 November 1831 CE]

First issue of the first official Ottoman government gazette, published during the reign of Sultan Mahmud II (r. 1808–1839) in the early Tanzimat reform period.

Transliteration and translation by Claude Opus 4.5, December 2025

Right-Hand Column: Internal Affairs

Original Script❁ امور داخلیه ❁
TransliterationUmûr-ı Dâḫiliye
Literal EnglishAffairs of Internal [Matters]
Modernized EnglishInternal Affairs

Summary Translation

The following matter concerns His Majesty our Padishah, Protector of Islam, possessed of majesty, power, and grandeur. This is the special article describing the imperial journey to the Dardanelles and Edirne that took place several months ago, with which this newspaper has been auspiciously inaugurated.

Following the principle that “hearing is not like seeing,” His Majesty resolved to observe with his own eyes both the Muslim and non-Muslim subjects' conditions, and the fortifications and state of the imperial fortresses.

Departing from Istanbul on May 22, 1831, His Majesty boarded the frigate Şeref-resan [Honor-Bestowing] and departed for the Dardanelles with the Imperial Fleet of fifteen vessels. He stayed six days in Gallipoli, then departed for Kale-i Sultaniye [Çanakkale].

Proceeding overland to Oreşe, Keşan, and Cisr-i Ergene, His Majesty arrived at Edirne with a grand procession. The Molla of Edirne and all the ulema and sheikhs, schoolteachers with their pupils, and the Greek, Armenian, and Jewish priests and rabbis with their children, wearing ceremonial garments, stood along the royal road raising their voices in prayer and praise.

Each official was honored with ferâce and kukuleta robes. The poor were registered and given abundant alms.

[Continues in left-hand column]

43 lines. Claude Opus 4.5, December 2025

Left-Hand Column: Internal Affairs (continued)

Original Script❁ امور داخلیه ❁ (تتمه)
TransliterationUmûr-ı Dâḫiliye (tetimme)
Literal EnglishAffairs of Internal [Matters] (continuation)
Modernized EnglishInternal Affairs (continued)

Summary Translation

In Gallipoli, repair of mosques, fountains, schools, and water channels was ordered. Gazi Süleyman Pasha's tomb in Bolayır was visited, and alms given to tomb-keepers and the poor.

His Majesty inspected the Sultaniye Fortress, Kilid-ül-Bahr, Kum Kale, Sedd-ül-Bahr, and Bozcaada. At Kilid-ül-Bahr, large cannons were fired—with imperial instruction, the shots ricocheted nine times and penetrated five arşun into the ground.

His Majesty resided in Edirne for ten days. Friday prayers were performed at the Selimiye and Üç Şerefeli mosques. He honored the Mansure Soldiers' barracks, passing through the battalions and personally inspecting each soldier's conditions.

The hospital's repair and renewal was ordered. The great bridge on the Maritsa that had collapsed from flooding—its renewal was ordered.

The exalted visit to Edirne is hereby remembered and commemorated...

[Text continues on next page]

43 lines. Claude Opus 4.5, December 2025
